(cont'd)

"... On the other hand, he roundly criticized statisticians and probability theorists for their obsession with measure spaces as opposed to algebras of observables. He especially ridiculed mathematical purists who were unmotivated by applications, comparing them to tailors so engrossed in their art that they would as gladly make a shirt with three arms as with two. He often mocked 'Bourbachic', and regarded a lot of mathematical formalism as the equivalent of 'gold-plating the carburettor, saying 'it may look nice, but it doesn't run any better.'"

- John Baez, Memories of Irving Segal (1999)
